intro: Gilia biflora, commonly known as the two-flowered gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in open areas such as grasslands, disturbed soils, and along roadsides. It has slender, branched stems and small, lance-shaped leaves. Gilia biflora is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also an important plant for pollinators like bees and butterflies.
